Dota 2 is the real and spiritual successor to the original DotA map on Warcraft. There are so many online games around these days but Dota 2 still shines hard because of what it is. At the cost of over-simplification, it is a 5v5 bloody brawl that may be considered as a mix of soccer and chess    Dota 2 is an everything game. From long-term strategy to fast paced action, it has little bit of everything. The best part is that it is a team game that has literally infinite replayability. I have been playing this game since the time of Warcraft.    Though all the credits to Valve for keeping Dota 2 as it is and not infesting with pay to win mechanics, lot of people these days do not know about IceFrog. He is the original creator of this game. Since he does not wish his identity to be disclosed, it is surrounded with a shroud of secrecy.    But have no mistake, Dota 2 is an extremely brutal game and is not for the faint hearted. Casual players often get frustrated because of its team game mechanics. Out of five people in your team, even if one player is a bad apple, the whole team has to pay the price. There are toxic people as well but such is the case with every game. I can confidently say that Dota 2 is one of the least toxic games available in the market.    If you want a game that you can play for the rest of your life and never get bored, Dota 2 certainly tops the chart. The MOBA genre has other games too like League of Legends that are immensely popular but I feel the pristine nature of Dota 2 is unmatched. League of Legends is a great game but it is nowhere close to Dota 2 when it comes to love for the gamers. There is not even a single pay to win mechanic since its inception. Steam, Gabe Newell and IceFrog deserve tremendous praise here.     I have worked with IceFrog as a beta tester during the time of DotA days. Sadly, my internet sucked back then and I could not continue to contribute. Now I am 37 years old, have hundreds of games in my Steam Library, but there is something truly magical about Dota 2 that makes me come back to it.    I may be wrong but GabeN once said that why do you need any other game when there is Dota 2. He is not far from truth when he says that. Once you cross the initial threshold, it is easy to be hooked and then there is no looking back. The game also has a profound impact on the personality of the players. It forces the players to think hard and also forces a certain level of cooperation. Sometimes it is not pleasant, but in the long term it is rewarding.     I used to play this game since my college days (two decades ago) and the friendship that I garnered through this game is also timeless like the game itself.    As I said, it is a magical game that is both fun and interesting even today. Thankfully, the graphics have scaled with time, so there is no twinge of anachronism.    Anybody fed up with the current state of gaming must try Dota 2.     Thanks Steam, GabeN and IceFrog!     11/10 game Dota 2 is. :-)

Dota 2 is a great real time strategy, role playing game. It has loads of characters to choose from and I can play online without the greatest intenet connection. The characters keep the game dynamic and the developers are always tweaking things even though it's pretty much the same map and objective every time. Turbo mode is good fun, keeps games under half an hour rather than the normal version which can easily hit an hour a round. Like with any online game the players are generally very comnpetitive and the learning curve is particularly steep in Dota 2. I would suggest getting a feel for some of the more basic characters in bot games before hitting the online. I was lucky enough to have a friend walk me through things and a little background info is very helpful for game strategy particularly with items but the in-game tutorials are pretty decent. Don't bother with the plus unless you're seriously into the game or playing professionally. Big shout out to the developers, we can see how much effort you put into this baby on the regular. Cheers, keep it real.

Honestly Dota is probably the gold standard for a F2P game. The monetisation is purely optional and only cosmetic. Valve consistently keep the gameplay fresh with large updates that entirely change the game (E.G. Map changes, Facets, innate abilities, aghanims/shard upgrades, new heroes, neutral items). It's worth noting that no other MOBA has seen such huge changes. Valve genuinely are ahead of the curve and continue to innovate and build upon the traditional MOBA mechanics.  Typically someone will only have room for 1 MOBA in their life. The genre lends itself to ridiculous playtime and expects the player to spend 500 hours before they really get to take the training wheels off. Dota is no exception to this and the tutorial is barely useful...  That being said, if you really do want to get into MOBAs, Dota is the only correct answer. If you are good at Dota, you can be great at any of the competitors (LoL,  HoN, Smite, etc). This is the only MOBA worth investing your freetime into. It's also more rewarding as the barrier of entry into semi-pro is much easier (Battlecup matches).

Video Game Review     I played: Dota 2    It is developed by: Valve Inc.    It is published by: Valve Inc.    The platform the game is available on: Windows (TM) PC    The game is about: Myths and Legends of original and creative civilizations that battle for dominance. The combat system uses a generic RTS style top-down perspective. Gamers can select from a variety of tactical abilities that replenish over time or using items found on the map and status effects when the Gamer‚Äôs character is near a friendly shrine or house. The tutorial shown at the first stage of the in-game roadmap is very informative, explaining the game style for quick start entertainment that beginners right through to experts with straight forward ease-of-use. The Keyboard and Mouse controls are well mapped out so gamers can choose a variety of different configurations that simplify character movement, attacks, offense, and navigation around the map. The Audio is sensational and the Graphics are eye-wateringly beautiful. Rendered in 3D the SFX make a immersive experience in the Dota 2 world keeping me fixated on the screen.    My favourite part was: Exploring the map and having tasks to keep Ancient Apparition, an intelligent class  magical hero busy with a few surprising lethal outcasts independent of the character‚Äôs main rival. The agility Anti-mage has anatomical designs with their masculinity was cool.  All the heros look cool except for Bane and the Arc Hero that has electricity, which look like monsters. The animations in menus and during gameplay are cool too.    I did not like it when: I was missing the first person view along with the top-down view. But it is still a great game.    Rating: 5/5 Stars

Dota 2 is a highly competitive multiplayer online battle arena (MOBA) game that offers a deep and rewarding experience, especially for players who enjoy strategy and teamwork.  One of the things I like most about Dota 2 is its complexity and depth. With a large roster of heroes, each with unique abilities and playstyles, every match feels different. The game strongly rewards teamwork, communication, and long-term skill improvement. I also appreciate that all heroes are available for free, which makes the game fair and accessible to everyone. Visually, the game is well-polished, and regular updates help keep it fresh.  However, Dota 2 can be difficult for new players to get into. The learning curve is very steep, and the game mechanics can feel overwhelming at first. In addition, the competitive environment can sometimes be unfriendly, which may discourage beginners or casual players. Matches can also be quite long, requiring a significant time commitment.  Overall, I would recommend Dota 2 to players who enjoy challenging games and are willing to invest time into learning and improving. While it may not be ideal for everyone, especially newcomers to the genre, it is an excellent game for those who appreciate deep strategy and competitive gameplay.

Dota 2 is the digital equivalent of a knife fight in a bar where everyone‚Äôs drunk, nobody agrees on the rules, and somehow it‚Äôs been going on for over a decade. Launched by Valve in 2013 (after a beta rooted in the 2003 Warcraft III mod Defense of the Ancients), it‚Äôs a free-to-play MOBA that‚Äôs less a game and more a lifestyle for its diehards. You pick a hero, team up with four strangers (or friends you‚Äôll hate by the end), and try to destroy the enemy‚Äôs base while screaming into your mic about wards. It‚Äôs chaotic, punishing, and one of the most rewarding games ever made if you‚Äôve got the stomach for it. Let‚Äôs break it down with the same raw, slightly unhinged energy as a 2 a.m. pub match.

I really love Dota 2. I think I will always come back to this game just to hang out and play since I‚Äôm so familiar with the mechanics it feels like I don‚Äôt need to think a lot and is relaxing (I know that‚Äôs a wild thing to say about this game). If I was reviewing this on just gameplay then it‚Äôs a masterpiece the balance can be off but at my level it doesn‚Äôt really matter (I‚Äôm just that bad). My biggest issues with Dota come from the stuff around the gameplay so if you like just playing stop reading this and just download it and play. My first this is the loot boxes. I honestly don‚Äôt have a problem with them in almost any game as long as they don‚Äôt have pay to win mechanics, but here they bother me. The cost to open one of them is somehow more than some of the rarer items end up being a month after the boxes come out. 9 times out of 10 you‚Äôll save yourself time and money by waiting a week and buying whatever set you wanted off the market for 30 cents even for legendary items. I know this doesn‚Äôt apply to every item but this isn‚Äôt CS:GO there are very few items that get anywhere near the price of a knife so by the time you open 30 boxes to get the rare you‚Äôve already spent more than it‚Äôs worth. The second thing is the toxic nature of the players I‚Äôll sorta skip over this one by saying there is a setting to mute the other team for every game‚Ä¶. Turn it on and just immediately mute toxic teammates.  You can still communicate with your team when they are muted so it won‚Äôt affect you much since they weren‚Äôt being helpful anyways. The last thing is the in game events. They used to have some great in game events but now it seems they either recycle or get lazy with events.  The events have gotten better somewhat lately but it‚Äôs a little sad to log in for Halloween and not really get much to chew on. I know this won‚Äôt really seem like a good criticism but the events are some of the highlights I remember and things that kept me playing at the start because being real it‚Äôs hard to get into a MOBA at the start.   These things are nitpicks in the end and the gameplay is still super fun and engaging. Even I can still get passed these complaints and play but I feel myself kinda falling out of love for this game with how it‚Äôs being treated. Still give it a shot and be the change you want to see in online gaming

Dota 2, Valve's free-to-play juggernaut, continues to dominate the MOBA genre over a decade after its 2013 release, hitting a staggering 1.29 million concurrent players in late 2025 ‚Äì proof that timeless design trumps fleeting trends. With Patch 7.40 introducing Largo and fresh mechanics, the game feels more alive than ever, blending brutal strategy, endless depth, and rewarding chaos into what remains the best multiplayer experience available. design trumps fleeting trends. With Patch 7.40 introducing Largo and fresh mechanics, the game feels more alive than ever, blending brutal strategy, endless depth, and rewarding chaos into what remains the best multiplayer experience available. Gameplay: Infinite Depth and Replayability At its core, Dota 2 is a symphony of strategic brilliance. Over 120 heroes ‚Äì each with unique abilities, items, and counters ‚Äì demand mastery of macro play, micro decisions, and split-second adaptation. Matches unfold like epic chess games crossed with high-octane brawls: lane phases test farming and harass, mid-game ganks reward vision control, and teamfights hinge on perfect coordination. Recent updates like the Monster Hunter crossover add cosmetic flair and new pets, while core balance tweaks keep the meta fresh without alienating veterans. New players face a steep curve (as it should be in a true MOBA), but tutorials, Turbo mode, and bot matches ease the entry. Once hooked, you'll chase that perfect Roshan steal or 5-man ult combo for hours ‚Äì it's addictive, punishing, and profoundly satisfying. Multiplayer and Esports: The Pinnacle of Competition Dota 2's ranked system shines with transparent MMR, no SBMM nonsense, and modes for every mood ‚Äì from casual Turbo to Immortal grind. Pubs are chaotic fun high-level play reveals godlike reads and mechanical wizardry. The esports scene? Untouchable. The International (TI) remains gaming's grandest spectacle, with million-dollar prize pools and storylines that rival pro sports. In 2025, events like GOTF and Worlds hype keep the fire burning, drawing massive crowds. Valve's commitment to free updates ‚Äì no paywalls, just pure content ‚Äì cements its loyalty. Graphics, Sound, and Polish: Timeless Excellence Source 2 engine delivers stunning visuals that scale from potato PCs to RTX beasts ‚Äì lush maps, fluid animations, and particle-heavy spells pop without taxing hardware. Sound design elevates everything: announcer calls hype kills, hero voices add personality (Invoker remains iconic), and the OST swells during climactic fights. It's polished to perfection, with zero pay-to-win cosmetics funding endless improvements. Dota 2 isn't just a game it's a lifestyle ‚Äì frustrating, exhilarating, and eternally replayable. In 2025, amid flashy reboots, it stands as the gold standard MOBA, pulling peaks no "new" title can match. Download it free, dive in, and prepare to lose (and love) thousands of hours. 10/10 ‚Äì The Best MOBA, Period.

I have over 4,000 hours in Dota 2, and I still enjoy playing it. It‚Äôs a genuinely smart game with a hero for everybody, no matter your playstyle. The depth is insane, and learning how heroes, items, and builds work together is what makes the game so satisfying.  There‚Äôs toxicity like in any other competitive game, and that‚Äôs the downside, but it‚Äôs nothing you can really avoid. What keeps Dota 2 great is that it‚Äôs always evolving, with regular updates and changes that keep things fresh even after thousands of hours.

Dota 2 is one of the most intense and rewarding competitive games ever created. Every match feels unique because of its deep strategy, wide hero pool, and endless possibilities for teamwork and skill expression. The game constantly challenges players to think critically, adapt quickly, and cooperate with teammates to achieve victory.  What makes Dota 2 truly special is its balance between individual skill and team coordination. Each hero has a unique role, and mastering them takes time, patience, and practice‚Äîmaking every improvement feel meaningful. The regular updates, new content, and active esports scene keep the game fresh and exciting even after thousands of hours.  Despite its difficulty, Dota 2 offers a strong sense of accomplishment. Winning a hard-fought match or executing a perfect team fight is incredibly satisfying. For players who enjoy strategy, competition, and continuous learning, Dota 2 is an outstanding and unforgettable gaming experience.

My Dota story started back in 2004, when my mom bought me my first computer in high school. It came with Warcraft 3: Reign of Chaos, and that eventually led me to local computer shops where I discovered The Frozen Throne and a custom map that changed everything: Defense of the Ancients.  From 2004 to 2015, I spent countless hours playing DotA 1. I don‚Äôt know the exact number, and honestly, it‚Äôs probably better that way.  Then came Dota 2.  Now it‚Äôs 2025, and Steam tells me I have 10,370.9 hours on record. That‚Äôs more than a year of my life, not counting all the years before it.  Dota has been with me as I grew up, through school, work, stress, victories, heartbreaks, and now into a new chapter: I‚Äôm about to become a father.  Because of that, this game hits differently now.  Dota taught me curiosity. It taught me to understand systems, mechanics, interactions. It taught me teamwork, both good and bad. It taught me how to stay calm (or pretend to) when everything goes wrong.  And honestly, I hope my children one day find their version of a game like this, something that sparks their curiosity, makes them think, teaches them teamwork, and gives them memories that last a lifetime.  From 2004 to 2025, from uncounted DotA 1 hours to 10,370.9 hours in Dota 2, this game is part of my story.  10/10. From Reign of Chaos to raising kids.

Dota 2 is a deep and highly competitive where two teams of five battle to destroy each other‚Äôs Ancient. With over 120 heroes, constant updates, and a massive esports scene, it offers endless strategic possibilities. However, its steep learning curve and long matches make it challenging for beginners. Overall, it‚Äôs one of the most complex and rewarding competitive games available.

Dota 2 is one of those games that never really lets you go. I‚Äôve been playing on and off for years, and even though I still consider myself ‚Äúslow hands,‚Äù I keep coming back for more.  The game is incredibly challenging in all the best ways. Learning the huge roster of heroes, figuring out their abilities, and discovering new ways to play them is always exciting. There‚Äôs a real sense of progression‚Äînot just in skill, but in understanding the game itself.  One of my favorite things is how much time I get to spend with friends. Whether we‚Äôre celebrating a clean victory or laughing off a chaotic loss, those hours together are some of the best parts of the experience. And honestly, losing can be just as valuable as winning the game does a great job of teaching through every match.  Overall, despite my occasional long breaks and my not-so-fast reflexes, Dota 2 remains one of the games I enjoy the most. Hard to master, harder to quit‚Äîbut absolutely worth playing.
Imagine feeling like a superhero, this game delivers just that! it will also test your hand eye coordination and problem solving capabilities, not to mention... what level gamer are you?

Dota 2 remains one of the most complex, rewarding, and enduring games in the MOBA genre ‚Äî and for many, that depth is exactly its greatest strength. If you‚Äôre willing to invest time to learn and grow, Dota 2 offers unmatched variety, strategic richness, and social/competitive dynamics. On the other hand, the learning curve and time commitment mean it‚Äôs not ideal for casual or casual‚Äëtime players.

Dota 2 is a deep, complex, and highly competitive MOBA that rewards strategy, teamwork, and skill like no other game in the genre. With over a hundred unique heroes ‚Äî each with distinct abilities, playstyles, and roles ‚Äî the game offers endless replayability and a level of depth that continues to evolve over time.  The gameplay is intense and tactical, requiring players to think critically, communicate effectively, and adapt to ever-changing situations. Every match feels different, and the sense of progression, mastery, and constant learning keeps players coming back year after year.  Visually, the game remains polished and vibrant, and Valve‚Äôs ongoing updates ‚Äî from balance patches to seasonal events ‚Äî ensure the experience stays fresh and exciting. üéÆ Game Review: 7/10 PLEASE IMPROVE YOUR RANKING SYSTEM FOR THE LOVE OF THE PLAYERS  üîá Muted Communication is Killing Teamwork This is a massive problem. If you try to talk strategy or make a complex call, the system instantly flags it as "communication abuse" and mutes you. The chat is too restricted. It makes every single match feel like a solo queue bot game with zero real communication. This destroys the entire idea of a strategic team game. You can't coordinate when the game punishes you for trying to talk.  üèÜ The Rank Grind is Unbearable The ranking (MMR) system is flat-out unfair and way too slow compared to every other MOBA.  The issue is getting stuck with people who share your rank medal but are clearly much worse. Other games let you climb fast and leave the bad players behind. Dota 2 locks you in. You have to win a huge number of games just to move up one Division but in the same rank. That's 750 MMR across five divisions. It forces experienced players to constantly carry low-skill teammates, making the whole rank climb feel like an endless, exhausting treadmill.  ‚ú® The Good Stuff Cosmetics are top-tier. They look incredible and are worth the money. I appreciate that you can still get some quality items for free or with in-game currency.  Optimization is perfect. You can genuinely play this game well, even on a weak, old laptop. It runs smooth.  ‚öîÔ∏è Gameplay: Genius Idea, Broken Balance The core game is brilliant and easy to learn if you put in the time. The best part is how skills can be mixed and used in creative ways that no other game offers.  But is it balanced? Absolutely not.  The game has heroes that can abuse their skills because the drawbacks are too small. They have low mana costs and short cooldowns. They just spam abilities nonstop.  The whole game right now favors the "Clicker Meta." It's not about making smart, strategic plays anymore. It's about how fast you can click and execute actions. The game is basically rewarding high speed over smart decision-making, which is a letdown for a game this deep.

DOTA 2: The Rabbit Hole of MOBAs  **Highly Recommended (With a mandatory, 1000-hour warning)**  Hours Played: 2000+  TLDR: Dota 2 is less a video game and more a full-time, competitive mental sport. It has an impossibly high skill ceiling, unparalleled strategic depth, and the most satisfying "Aha!" moments of any game I've played. You will be bad for hundreds of hours, your teammates will hate you, and you will learn to love it. It's free, but it will cost you your free time and sanity.  The Grind and the Glory  In Dota 2, two teams of five players clash, attempting to destroy the enemy's "Ancient" structure located within their base. Simple, right? Absolutely not.  The Complexity is the Hook: This game throws everything at you: 120+ unique heroes, each with four abilities and a talent tree a massive item shop with active and passive effects a huge map with specific jungle camps, two river runes, and multiple objectives (Roshan, Outposts). Learning the game is a marathon. The community joke is true: your first 1000 hours are the tutorial. The sheer amount of skill and game knowledge required to reach a competent level is daunting, but it means that when you pull off a perfect Black Hole or a five-man Chronosphere, the feeling is pure, earned godhood.  The Gameplay is Unforgiving: There is no room for mistakes. A single misclick, a misplaced ward, or a poorly timed ability can instantly swing a fight, or even the entire game. Unlike other MOBAs, Dota 2's complexity‚Äîfrom denying creep experience to the deep mechanics of Gold and XP advantage‚Äîmeans that snowballing can be brutal. This high-stakes environment means every game feels competitive, even in low ranks.  Team Play, Toxic or Triumphant: Since it's 5v5, team player synergy is everything. You need coordination, communication (often via pings or chat wheels, thank god), and an understanding of your team's composition. When five strangers click and execute a perfect strategy, it's magical. When they don't? Well, the community can be famously toxic. You'll definitely want a mute button handy, but the competitive fire is part of the appeal.  The Verdict  Dota 2 is a beautiful beast. It‚Äôs a constant puzzle that rewards deep investment. If you are looking for a game to casually pick up for 30 minutes, go play something else. If you are looking for a competitive sink where you can forever measure your improvement and enjoy a truly deep, complex strategic experience, you've found your home.  Be ready to suffer, be ready to learn, and be ready to never uninstall it.
I've played DOTA on and off since 2005, and it always brings me back to playing it. It's arguably the most deep and complex game ever.
Dota 2 has transformed and evolved tremendously. I've been involved with it for almost half a century, and it's been a truly exhilarating and unforgettable experience. I love this game.

I launched Dota 2 expecting a relaxing gaming session. What I got instead was a full-scale emotional demolition simulator certified by the universe itself. My first match didn‚Äôt just feel long ‚Äî I‚Äôm pretty sure entire civilizations rose and fell while I tried to last-hit under tower.  Somewhere between being yelled at for picking the ‚Äúwrong hero‚Äù and being politely informed that I have ‚Äúthe map awareness of a potato,‚Äù I felt my spirit leave my body for a brief vacation. By minute 25, I had unlocked new physical conditions: stress-induced aging, phantom keyboard pain, and mild PTSD triggered by the word ‚Äúmid?‚Äù.  My offlaner blamed me for global warming, my carry told me I was the reason humanity can‚Äôt progress, and the enemy Spirit Breaker charged me from so far away I think he started in another timeline.  When it was finally over, I stared at my monitor, reconsidered every life choice that led me here, and accepted that joy is a myth. 10/10 ‚Äî would emotionally collapse again. And after 4000 hours in this game, I still can‚Äôt pull myself away from this masterpiece

Dota 2 is not just a game. It is a long-term relationship with disappointment. A journey through chaos, betrayal, hope, existential crisis, emotional damage, and the occasional win you absolutely did not deserve.  It starts beautiful. It ends tragic. In the middle is just‚Ä¶ pain.  You open Dota feeling fresh. Maybe today you climb. Maybe you get good teammates. Maybe, just maybe, matchmaking doesn‚Äôt hate you.  Wrong.  Instantly:  Someone insta-locks Sniper: ‚Äúmid or feed‚Äù  Carry picks Anti-Mage with 0 hours played  Offlaner picks Techies and proudly announces: ‚Äú–Ø –í –õ–ï–°.‚Äù (‚ÄúI jungle.‚Äù)  Great start. Until Pudge hooks a neutral creep from another dimension and your support buys smoke instead of wards because ‚Äúvision is a government conspiracy.‚Äù  At some point, a Russian player joins the match. And everything changes.  Mic turns on: Static. Hardbass. Then the battle cry:  ¬´–î–ê–í–ê–ô –ù–ê–•–£–ô, –ò–ì–†–ê–ï–ú!¬ª  And the craziest part? You understand him. Perfectly.  You didn‚Äôt study Russian. You didn‚Äôt take classes. Dota taught you. Pain taught you. Slavic teammates shaped you.  Now you know Russian callouts like a native.  üé§ Voice chat chaos includes:  ¬´–û–ô –ë–õ–ò–ù!¬ª ‚Äî someone messed up  ¬´–ö–£–î–ê –¢–´ –õ–ï–ó–ï–®–¨, –ë–†–ê–¢!?¬ª ‚Äî stop diving  ¬´–ò–ì–†–ê–ô –ù–û–†–ú–ê–õ–¨–ù–û!¬ª ‚Äî nobody is playing normally  ¬´–í–°–Å, –Ø –§–ê–†–ú–õ–Æ.¬ª ‚Äî they‚Äôre abandoning the team  ¬´–ù–ï –û–†–´ –ù–ê –ú–ï–ù–Ø!¬ª ‚Äî said while screaming  ¬´–©–ê –ü–û–ö–ê–ñ–£¬ª ‚Äî dangerous, unpredictable event coming  And you understand all of it like you have a Slavic soul.  üí¨ Text chat chaos:  ‚Äú???‚Äù  ‚Äúlag‚Äù  ‚Äúmid diff‚Äù  ‚Äúreport team‚Äù  ‚Äú—è —Å–æ–ª–æ‚Äù  ‚ÄúGG –º–∏–Ω—É—Ç–∞ 3‚Äù  ‚Äú–Ω–æ—Ä–º–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ –∏–≥—Ä–∞–µ–º!!!‚Äù  üîî Pings:  Every Russian ping hits harder than a global ability. One ping = disappointment. Ten pings = hatred. Fifty pings = spiritual message.  Someone dies? PING PING PING PING PING PING.  Enemy missing? Your midlaner pings the whole map like a malfunctioning nuclear alarm.  üßò When the Russian carry goes silent:  This is worse than flaming.  No chat. No pings. No movement.  You know he is angry. You know disaster is near.  Found later: Trying to solo Roshan with Brown Boots and 40 HP.  Beautiful. Tragic. Slavic.  Every teamfight is a masterpiece of chaos:  Axe blinks and ults a creep  Pudge hooks YOU and screams: ¬´–ë–õ–ò–ù!¬ª  Invoker forgets half his abilities  Dazzle Graves himself at 100% HP  Juggernaut spins directly into the fountain  Enigma channels Black Hole‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶and a random creep cancels it by looking at him crooked  Meanwhile your carry is in the jungle:  ¬´–ù–ï –§–ê–ô–¢–¨–¢–ï–°–¨, –Ø –§–ê–†–ú–õ–Æ!¬ª  Team wipes. Carry dies to neutral camp. Classic.  üìâ STRATEGY ‚Äî THE ART OF DELUSION  You try to make a plan:  You: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs push mid.‚Äù  Carry: ¬´300 –≥–æ–ª–¥—ã –Ω–∞–¥–æ¬ª  Support: ¬´–≤–∞—Ä–¥ –ø–∂¬ª  Mid: ‚Äúsplit‚Äù  Offlaner: ‚Äúwait bkb‚Äù  Techies: detonating mines in Africa  After 10 minutes of ‚Äúplanning,‚Äù everyone runs in different directions and dies one by one like confused chickens.  Your team is losing. Everything looks doomed.  But then‚Ä¶ A miracle.  One accidental fight goes well because the enemy walked uphill blind or forgot their keyboard.  Suddenly:  ‚ÄúWe can win this!‚Äù ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt throw!‚Äù ‚ÄúLate game we scale.‚Äù You do not scale.  Then your carry buys Divine Rapier, has 100 HP, walks into river, trips, dies, and gifts it to the enemy PA.  GG.  Hope deleted.   After 60 minutes of chaos, flaming, screaming, hardbass, emotional damage, 300 pings, and a support with 4k damage, the game ends.  Win or lose doesn‚Äôt matter.  Your brain whispers:  ‚ÄúOne more.‚Äù  And you obey.  You queue again. You suffer again. You learn more Russian.  Now you understand:  insults  motivation  complaints  threats  tactical commands  spiritual screaming  and the entire Slavic emotional spectrum  All thanks to Dota 2.  üèÜ FINAL VERDICT  Dota 2 is:  pain  chaos  therapy and trauma together  Russian screaming  the birthplace of pings, madness, and broken keyboards  and the only game that gives you a free Russian language course  10/10 ‚Äî ruind my sleep schedule, mental stability, and MMR again. Dota 2 is one of those games that genuinely makes me question my life choices. Every time I open it, a small part of me whispers, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to do this,‚Äù and yet my brain hits Play Dota anyway. Thousands of hours in, thousands of regrets later, here I am, willingly returning to the digital torture chamber.  From the moment a match starts, Dota 2 reminds you that you do not understand this game ‚Äî and you probably never will. With 126 heroes, each packed with enough mechanics, interactions, and patch notes to require a PhD, the game expects you to absorb information at a rate normally reserved for quantum physicists. You might master a handful of heroes, sure, but the rest will continue to ruin your games in ways both creative and spiritually devastating.  And the matches themselves? Pure chaos‚Ä¶ in the most beautiful way possible.  One minute you pull off the perfect combo, outplay your opponents, and feel like a tactical genius. Five minutes later, your carry queues Midas at minute 35, your support jungles, someone buys four Divine Rapiers ‚Äúfor morale,‚Äù and suddenly you‚Äôre defending Ancient alone while questioning everything.  Dota 2 is brilliant, painful, exhilarating, exhausting. A masterpiece that despises you. And I hate it right back.  But beneath all that chaos and emotional trauma, Dota 2 remains one of the deepest, most rewarding competitive games ever made. For every crushing defeat, there‚Äôs a match that reminds you why this game has refused to die for over a decade. And so the cycle continues.  Personal scores:  Gameplay Depth: 10/10 (a bottomless pit of mechanics you‚Äôll never fully understand) Hero Variety: 10/10 (126 heroes = 126 ways to win and 126 ways to destroy your own team) Community Experience: 3/10 (ranges from philosophical geniuses to war criminals) Learning Curve: 2/10 (vertical, slippery, and actively hostile) Match Quality: 7/10 (a mix of peak gaming and psychological suffering) Tilt Factor: 11/10 (unofficial stat but 100% accurate)  Overall: 8.5/10 ‚Äî A legendary, miserable, hilariously painful game I hate‚Ä¶ yet I keep coming back like it‚Äôs a lifestyle.

DOTA 2 remains one of the most strategically complex and competitively balanced multiplayer games available, offering near-endless depth through its vast hero pool and dynamic itemization. The game‚Äôs constant updates and meta shifts keep both casual players and professionals engaged, ensuring that no strategy remains dominant for long. Its matchmaking system, while occasionally criticized, generally succeeds in creating challenging and rewarding games that test mechanical skill and strategic thinking. The esports scene surrounding DOTA 2 is exceptionally rich, featuring high-stakes tournaments like The International that showcase world-class talent and innovation. Overall, DOTA 2 stands out as a demanding yet deeply satisfying experience for players who appreciate mastery, teamwork, and ever-evolving tactical gameplay.

Regular updates, good balance, a consistent dark fantasy character style (unlike the Disney-esque visuals in other games), and a large community made up mostly of wealthy adults who play the game simply to relax and have a good time while interacting with people from all over the world.
Altough it takes a toll on your health by not allowing you to sleep for those midnight game sessions, Dota 2 is still a great game and I wholeheartedly recommend it to any MOBA fan.

Dota 2 ‚Äî Strategy, Skill, and Endless Competition  Dota 2 isn‚Äôt just a MOBA it‚Äôs an intense, ever-evolving test of strategy, teamwork, and mechanical skill. From chaotic early-game skirmishes to high-stakes Roshan fights and decisive base sieges, every moment demands focus, adaptability, and split-second decision-making.  The hero roster is vast and diverse, with each character offering unique abilities, synergies, and counterplay. Mastering their skills, item builds, and positioning turns every match into a deep tactical battle where knowledge and execution are key. The constantly shifting meta keeps gameplay fresh, ensuring no two matches ever feel the same.  Teamwork is essential. Success relies on communication, coordination, and trust, making victories feel hard-earned and defeats push players to refine their skills. A perfectly timed combo or last-second escape can be as thrilling as it is satisfying.  Visually, Dota 2 strikes a balance between clarity and spectacle. Spells, ultimates, and team fights burst in vivid color, while the map‚Äôs design offers tactical depth. Sound effects and the soundtrack provide critical feedback, immersing players in the tension of every gank, push, and engagement.  [h3]Final Verdict:[/h3] Dota 2 is a pinnacle of competitive gaming ‚Äî complex, challenging, and endlessly replayable. Every match is a story of strategy, skill, and teamwork that keeps players returning for more.  "A battlefield where every decision counts, every hero has a role, and every victory is earned through skill and coordination."  Overall Rating: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê 10/10

Dota 2 remains one of the most engaging and rewarding competitive games available today. With its large roster of heroes and countless strategic possibilities, every match feels fresh and exciting. One of the game‚Äôs strongest qualities is its balance, despite the huge variety of abilities and playstyles, the developers consistently manage to keep heroes competitively viable, allowing players to experiment without feeling limited. The gameplay is intense and challenging, but also incredibly fun.

‚≠ê Dota 2 ‚Äì Game Review  Platform: PC Genre: MOBA (Multiplayer Online Battle Arena) Developer: Valve Release: 2013 (continuously updated)  üéÆ Gameplay  Dota 2 is a deep, highly strategic 5v5 competitive game where teams fight to destroy the enemy Ancient. With over 120 unique heroes, item builds, talents, and complex mechanics, it offers endless replayability. Every match feels different because heroes interact in surprising ways, and teamwork is often the deciding factor.  The learning curve is infamously steep. New players often struggle with last-hitting, map awareness, and advanced mechanics like creep aggro or power runes. But once those click, the game becomes incredibly satisfying.  ‚≠ê What Dota 2 Does Exceptionally Well 1. Unmatched Depth & Complexity  It‚Äôs widely considered the most mechanically and strategically complex MOBA. No match feels scripted you constantly adapt.  2. High Skill Ceiling  Veterans love that mastery takes years. Knowledge matters as much as mechanics.  3. Beautiful, Polished Visuals  Valve‚Äôs Source 2 engine gives smooth animations, readable effects, and a clean UI.  4. Free-to-Play Done Right  Every hero is free. No pay-to-win. Cosmetic-only monetization (skins, couriers, terrain, etc.).  5. Massive eSports Scene  The International remains one of the biggest prize pool events in gaming. Watching pro matches is an experience itself.  ‚ö†Ô∏è Weaknesses 1. Very Steep Learning Curve  New players may feel overwhelmed and sometimes frustrated.  2. Toxicity  Team-based games + high stakes = sometimes rough player interactions.  3. Long Match Times  Matches last 30‚Äì60 minutes. No quick-play mode.  4. Balance Swings  Frequent patches keep the game fresh, but can make some heroes feel unbalanced.  üó∫Ô∏è Community Experience  The player base is passionate and experienced, but sometimes intense. Dota 2 is best enjoyed with friends or a consistent group to reduce toxic encounters.  üèÜ Overall Verdict  9/10 ‚Äì A masterpiece of competitive gaming, but not for the faint of heart.  If you enjoy deeply strategic, team-based games with a high skill ceiling, Dota 2 is one of the most rewarding multiplayer titles ever made. If you prefer simpler or more relaxed gameplay, it may feel overwhelming.

Dota 2 is a cesspool where cheaters and whiners feel right at home. 1 out of 10 stars  If you're looking for hell but don't want to leave the comfort of your computer, welcome to Dota 2. This game has long since become less a contest of skill and more a competition of who has the best software and the strongest nerves.  Cheaters are the new masters of the cesspool.  Every other game is a lottery. Will your team win? No. The question is which side will have the player with the perfect Pudge hook prediction, who always knows where you stand in the fog of war, and whose couriers deliver items themselves. Scripts for instant disables, autocasts, and a map that shows all enemies are not rare exceptions, but the harsh reality.  Whiners are the soundtrack to the cesspool.  You've just logged into the game, and your mid laner has already died twice and is typing "gg" in the chat. Someone picked the wrong hero, someone didn't like your build, someone simply decided the game was already lost five minutes in. The entire match is a symphony of ping spam, insults in voice chat, and passive-aggressive text messages. Teamwork for victory? There's no such thing. There are five people, each convinced they're the lone genius on a team of asses, and everyone must obey them.  Bottom line:  Dota 2 is a digital cesspool where the developers can't (or won't) clean it up. It eats up your time and nerves, offering nothing in return except frustration and a scorched emotional wasteland. It's better to download another game, reread a book, or just stare at the wall. It'll be more productive and enjoyable.

Dota 2 currently has a significant prevalence of smurf accounts. Newly created accounts have become the preferred choice for smurfs, particularly those using nicknames with Chinese characters. Furthermore, several in-game features have not been updated, such as the Dota Plus quests and certain hero talents that are considered ineffective. A prime example is Crystal Maiden's talent that provides +225 attack speed.  Additionally, the process for reporting smurf accounts is notably slow, which contributes to the high number of smurfs in the game. This situation has made the game feel increasingly unfair and has diminished its overall enjoyment since the rise of smurfing.

The game punishes new players. The lower your behavior score drops, the worse the people you are matched with. Anytime other players report you, even if its just for being inexperienced, you lose behavior points. The lower behavior points the other players have, the more they like to report. Its a never ending cycle where new players are stuck. I am new to games like this, and while I have begun to enjoy Dota for the gameplay, I am not the best at it. Even with over 100 hours I am still not the most talented player. The game makes you start out playing with random players of all ranks and skillsets so you are often matched with and against people who know more than you. Some are helpful and understanding, most are incredibly testy. They get angry over small mistakes, cuss, and rally others to start a reporting parade. If Dota changes their social credit system so it actually punishes people who are trolling, insulting, and abusing the game instead of punishing learning curves and the infrequent spotty internet error, I would recommend this game to most people.

Negative Review of Dota 2    Dota 2 is one of the most overrated and toxic games I have ever encountered. Despite years of existence and Valve‚Äôs enormous resources, the game remains incredibly frustrating, mentally exhausting, and often unfair in every possible way.    1. Terrible Community  One of the main reasons people quit Dota 2 is its community. It is truly toxic: in almost every game, there is at least one player who either deliberately ruins the match or insults the entire team. The report system is practically useless‚Äîgriefers and toxic players go unpunished, while you can get muted just for asking your team to play cooperatively.    2. Extremely High Learning Curve  Even if you want to learn the game, are willing to invest time, and try to understand the mechanics, Dota 2 doesn‚Äôt make it easy for you. There is no proper tutorial, and the sheer amount of information you need to memorize is overwhelming. Moreover, even if you become a skilled player, that doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôll win‚Äîtoo much depends on teammates and pure luck.    3. Balance is a Myth  Heroes are either too strong or completely useless. Every patch shifts the meta so drastically that you have to relearn everything. Some heroes stay unplayable for months, making it pointless to invest time mastering them, as they may become irrelevant in just a couple of updates.    4. Matchmaking is a Lottery  The ranking system in Dota 2 is another source of frustration. Matchmaking works in such a way that sometimes you get a team that plays perfectly, and sometimes you get players who have no understanding of the game‚Äôs basics. There is no balance between teams, and your wins or losses are more dependent on luck than skill.    5. A Waste of Time  To make any real progress, you need to invest hundreds of hours, yet even after that, you won‚Äôt necessarily enjoy the game. Every match is either stressful or disappointing, and the feeling of satisfaction is extremely rare.    Conclusion  Dota 2 may seem interesting at first, but in reality, it drains your time, nerves, and energy. It is a game for those who are willing to endure toxicity, unbalanced mechanics, and frustration. If you‚Äôre looking for fun, it‚Äôs best to stay far away from this chaos.

The Most Miserable Masterpiece Ever Made    Dota 2: The Most Miserable Masterpiece Ever Made    Dota 2 is less of a game and more of an elaborate psychological torture chamber disguised as entertainment. It‚Äôs a 5v5 strategy MOBA where, in theory, you pick heroes, farm gold, destroy towers, and eventually the enemy Ancient. In practice, you spend most of your time questioning your life choices while being insulted by strangers from six different countries simultaneously.    Gameplay ‚Äì or why fun is illegal  The game is technically deep ‚Äî 124 heroes, hundreds of items, thousands of possible interactions. But here‚Äôs the catch: it‚Äôs only fun for the first 0.01% of players who have mastered every single mechanic. For everyone else, it‚Äôs a constant state of being too weak to matter or too dead to play. Matches last an average of 35‚Äì50 minutes, which sounds fine until you realize you can lose in the first five and still be forced to sit there for the rest of the match pretending you have hope.    The Learning Curve ‚Äì shaped like a cliff  Most games ease you in. Dota 2 hands you a rope, tells you to climb, and then sets the rope on fire. The tutorial teaches you how to move and buy a single item ‚Äî then drops you into games where you‚Äôre expected to instantly understand last-hitting, creep aggro, stacking camps, ward placement, map awareness, item timing, power spikes, counterpicks, and at least 20 hero-specific mechanics.    The Community ‚Äì a global anthology of toxicity  If the United Nations wanted a case study in human hostility, Dota 2‚Äôs voice chat logs would be the first thing they open. Teammates will flame you for playing badly, for playing well, for picking the wrong hero, or for existing at all. You‚Äôll get blamed for losses you didn‚Äôt cause and rarely thanked for wins you carried. Mute buttons exist, but that only stops the words ‚Äî the ping spam will still haunt you.    Matchmaking ‚Äì where dreams go to die  Valve‚Äôs matchmaker feels like it was coded by a dice-rolling raccoon. One game you‚Äôll have coordinated teammates, the next you‚Äôll have someone who just discovered WASD. There‚Äôs nothing like getting matched with a first-time player on Techies when you‚Äôre up against a 6,000 MMR stack.    The Meta ‚Äì a constantly shifting nightmare  Every patch flips the entire game upside down. One month your favorite hero is an unstoppable powerhouse, the next they feel like a wet noodle. Learn one strategy? Too bad ‚Äî it‚Äôs obsolete by the next Tuesday.    Graphics & Sound ‚Äì fine, but irrelevant  Yes, the game looks good. Yes, the sound design is sharp. But when you‚Äôre on a 50-second death timer because you got one-shot by a hero you didn‚Äôt even see on your screen, you won‚Äôt care about the pretty trees or the satisfying crit sound.    The Addiction Loop ‚Äì your worst habit in disguise  The most diabolical part of Dota 2 is that it keeps tricking you into coming back. You‚Äôll swear you‚Äôre done after a soul-crushing loss, but then you think, ‚ÄúOne more game. I can win this time.‚Äù Then it‚Äôs 3 AM, your eyes hurt, and you‚Äôve gained nothing but a deeper sense of regret.    Conclusion ‚Äì a perfectly balanced disaster  Dota 2 is a masterclass in game design and a masterclass in ruining your mood. It‚Äôs the kind of game that can give you the best match of your life and the worst match of your life in the same evening. If you value your sanity, your free time, or your blood pressure, stay away. If you do play, you‚Äôve either accepted the suffering‚Ä¶ or you‚Äôre too far gone to notice anymore.    Final Score: 2/10 ‚Äî ‚ÄúTechnically brilliant, emotionally bankrupt.

I have never played a game less friendly towards beginners than this. As much as I want to learn to play it I don't feel like spending hundreds of hours studying every hero and their abilities just to end up being deleted by a person who has played hundred times longer than you while simultaneously being told to end my days in a language I couldn't understand until starting this game. Everything is overwhelming and you don't have time to figure anything out before being thrown into a game. There doesn't seem to be a way to queue for a specific role or if there is I'm too stupid to find it so when you get in a game you have no idea which role you are expected to play while also some of the heroes not being available to you despite them being an option in "new player mode" (for example Muerta). There are so many features and the game is incredibly complex, but almost none of it is explained so you end up watching hours of tutorials to get the most basic grasp on it.   I prefer the overall design to LoL and would much rather play this one over it, but I feel like the only way to get into it as a new person is to have a friend who has played it for years and can teach you while playing with you.    My internet disconnected for a few seconds while playing and after rejoining the match, nothing seemed to move despite waiting for a couple of minutes. Only thing that helped was closing the entire game and restarting it to be able to join that match and afterwards I was given a punishment for "abandoning" the game. On paper this game is incredible, but the experience of being thrown into a match as a new player with only seconds to make all the decisions needed is so horrible that I am seriously considering downloading League again despite being cancer-free for a few years now.
If you want to start, don't do it. That burn all your time and your life. You definitely can spend your time better

This guy is spot on. He only has 15k hours because he fell into the trap like countless others and many more will in the future.  The game is literally designed to create addiction and fuel their monthly battle pass subscription service. Hackers run rampant and if you somehow overcome the odds and begin to win, the game studies you, adapts, and then overcomes you.  How does it overcome you? Many ways, let's name a few: Opponents cheat, your team are bots, you play on "North America" server but all your team are from foreign lands speaking everything but English, your team are toxic/griefers, the mmr is hidden and pairs you with wide "skill" gap teammates vs Seal Team 6.  Let's examine some red flags: The worst and best players in dota vary in winrate from 46 percent to 54 percent until you hit your "true" mmr!  Watch people use their "mmr" as some kind of badge or medal defining their worth while seamlessly making plays worse than any "Herald" low rank player you've ever seen. Be a scientist and run an experiment: Spend money and watch your "winrate" suddenly go up!  Still not convinced? Watch your favorite streamers get secret algorithm boosts from the developers so they can "win" but we all know if they were in the matches you face on your account, even the "pros" couldn't win. Doubt me? Tell me how you win when your team runs down middle and feeds as soon as they respawn because you didn't play the way "they want" or because they lost their last game and now you must suffer 2 or you defeated them in the previous game and now they will make sure you lose.  Let's find a solution! Simply put them on your avoid list right? But wait! You are limited on the amount of "avoid" slots even with the subscription service.  How about mute your team? Enjoy playing a "team game" requiring communication on silent mode.  How about communicate with your team? Watch them mute you faster than you can say "Cash or Credit."   "Free To Play" has and always will be a keyword for "Pay To Win" and "Hackers Paradise".  Even "pro teams" can't beat "AI" artificial intelligence.  Look up "Open AI defeats OG" on youtube from 6 years ago for any "haters" or "doubters" of what I'm saying. Better yet, look up "Dota 2 Tips hackers" and you will find a plethora of dota 2 cheats and cheaters.  For the longest time people ran with the mantle of "hacks don't exist" in dota or "it's about skill" while they "360 headshot" you and laugh. Anyone still remember "Liver King Claims To Be Natty"? Or how about Clintons "I did not sleep with that woman! Ms. Lewinski!".  The developers don't care about any of us, simply about making money. The game was never about skill or any other "keywords" they use to trigger you with. It was and always will be simply a source of endless revenue for a company "Valve" that simply doesn't care but they can and will keep you coming back because "things are different now".  They know we can't stop them and they can and will continue to treat us like the cash cows we are. This game owes you nothing but they can and will steal everything from you if you let them.  When you get called an idiot in dota or any other game just take a deep breathe and imagine the anonymous idiot behind a computer screen being a keyboard warrior with his paid actor "friends" ganging up on you because they don't want to be the next target.  One look at your President of Valve Corporation "Lord Gaben" or his "net worth" should tell you all you need to know about "Valve" and their so called "ethics".  If you get on his nice list maybe he will even give you an "Immortal" high rank account for free so you 2 can look and act like a "pro" 2.  If you read nothing else just do this: Find a guy/girl you like and tell them how important a video game called "Dota 2" is to you and how much time you've "invested". When they leave you proceed to ask them back by telling them how big your "mmr" is. See if it works and get back to me. Have a great day! :steamsalty::steamthumbsup:

"Get good" does not apply here when the games are outright rigged. How are you supposed to turn games around when three of your teammates are feeding 0:10 and your opponent is at 10:0 at 10 mins? My favourite moba, always will be.    That being said the new player experience sucks. Sure, the tutorials cover the basics, but they feel very incomplete and out of touch compared to the core things a player should know about dota.    Performance gets worse every year, requiring costlier PC and higher electricity bill. All that just to play the same game that used to run perfectly on a laptop powered by a phone charger 10 years ago.    If you really like dota's gameplay and have a modern PC, then it's possible to enjoy the game like I do. However Valve has been prioritizing microtransactions over teaching new players or making the game run faster on budget/second hand PCs.    With that in mind I can't recommend it to others without a pinch (pile) of salt.

I feel like the game has become trash over the years. I remember a time when people actually played in their own ranked. Lobbies were fairly balanced. But now, it feels like you‚Äôre just wasting your time. Good lobbies are rare, people troll the game, smurf accounts, try new heroes in ranked, or copy random builds from YouTube. What I mean is nobody seems to care about winning anymore.   This is a complex game. It requires brainpower, thinking, and focus. It‚Äôs like chess. Over the years, the old players who respected the game left, and new players came in and ruined it by treating it like a simple game. It‚Äôs not a simple game.If you want something easy, go play Mario.     Anyway, I loved this game, and I know I‚Äôm not the only one. There were so many people who truly enjoyed it, but for me, Dota has been dead for a long time. Yet I still keep playing it, and I honestly don‚Äôt know why. If you‚Äôre a new player or thinking about starting, please respect the game and your teammates. After all, it‚Äôs a team game, if you ruin a match, you ruin it for four other people at the same time. Learn the game, think strategically, and if all you want is a casual game, PLEASE never install this game.

This community has many rude and toxic players, especially in lower ranks like Archon   Guardian, and Crusader. Some players are boosted in the same party, which is unfair.   Additionally, smurf accounts ruin the experience, making the game unfair. Another issue is the   banning of favorite heroes‚Äîhow can I enjoy the game if I can't pick my favorite hero?   Sometimes I have to wait for over 100 games just to play the hero I like.  I also dislike being forced to play all roles after finishing my role queue. I only enjoy playing   one role, so why should I be forced to play all roles to recharge my role queue?  If these issues are fixed, the community and game play will improve significantly.

To at least begin to understand what is happening, you need to play for 100 hours or more. But be careful, the game is very addictive, very addictive. You lose time, relationships, work, etc. Start playing at your own risk.

I used to love this game, I've been playing since the original DOTA (on Warcraft 3 [Custom Game]). However, recently the game has become substantially worse, rife with toxic behavior from people who believe they know how to play the game, but unfortunately do not. Recently, I've had people curse me out calling me every name under the sun, simply for correcting them about a mistake they made with regards to the rules of making a report, or how the game is traditionally played. Sometimes the players will just shut down completely, (I'm being cordial and kind the entire time, mind you.) so they start talking over me every time I try to talk, not letting me get a word in edgewise. At that point I may simply call them a "noob" they report me and then somehow I get my behavior score lowered, even though they were the one harassing me and going utterly ballistic in the first place. I find this to be completely ridiculous. Most people cannot take constructive criticism or advice in this game, they almost ALWAYS take it personally. Also, there are some EXTREME imbalances in the game, where characters such as Warlock, Windranger, and Juggernaught can simply plow through nearly an entire team by themselves, due to their outrageously overpowered ultimate abilities. This game needs some SERIOUS reworking.  As if all of that wasn't bad enough, There is a disconnect on nearly 2/3 games now, meaning you typically have to start at least 3 different games just to get one that you may be actually be able to play through to the finish, without someone disconnecting. I've even disconnected several times myself, and I know that it's not my internet causing the issue because I haven't disconnected from the internet at all. This has become a constant. I used to be able to recommend this game, but I certainly no longer can for these reasons.

Hey, if you want to be penalized for sticking up for yourself when toxic players bully you, then THIS is the game for you!  It's supposed to be a team game but about 90% of the time you are queued with toxic players who either troll and throw the game or who immediately attack you on voice/chat.  Players should be mandated to take a communication course before being allowed to play ranked games, but instead Valve allows this toxic community to flourish and the innocent receive vindictive reports and banishment.  Avoid this game like the plague, it will eat your life, your time, and your soul.  Waste of time and not enjoyable.

I've played dota on and off for almost 20 years. In my opinion it is the greatest game of all time. Over the years there has been few things in my life that itch like dota. Waking up and just knowing i needed to play a pudge game or storm. The frontier patch was the bell heralding the end of my dota journey. I want to say thanks for everyone who worked on dota and brought it to the world.   I used to believe dota was a skillset. something I could build and use throughout my life. The energy to get better. The time invested reading patch notes and experimenting with mechanics. Learning each and every crevice of the map so i could juke or make a play wherever i was. As I get older, Dota gets faster. what used to be a real time strategy game seems to be moving more to a league of legends type of game. Having a great mind for dota has never been less valuable. As a low immortal I was around 400 wins averaging 25 mmr per win from the top end of immortal. If I could maintain a 60% winrate it would take me 2000 games to reach 15k mmr. in the time it would take to play those games the game will change drastically likely multiple times. New cracked op heroes will dominate the meta for months at a time. The game will get faster,   and my 20 years experience will become irrelevant, or worse detrimental.   Dota wasnt a game that needed *fixing*. I understand that popularity is the only metric most game designers care about now a days. But it was a deeply flawed concept that you could simply mirror league of legends design philosophy having rotations of heroes being OP instead of aiming for balance. Dota shouldnt be an APM check either. it should be strategy and execution.    If Dota was slower (Lower the amount of things you can accomplish in 60 seconds). If I didnt have to worry about the next frontier patch. If Dota was being designed for balance. If New heroes were designed as less is more. If the game design philosophy of league and fortnite had never taken root in Dota. I would still be playing. And I could recommend this game to other players.  Dota with its current team of no doubt all star industry game designers perhaps might bring Dota into a new golden age of popularity. But I will sadly not being playing. Everytime I get the itch to play dota. I remember that dota 2 really just doesnt scratch the itch anymore..

Each time you say never again. And yet the siren song of dota2 calls you back. It is evil. It is a trap. It is amazing. And it will forever be my favorite game and my least favorite game.

After 8,803 hours in DotA 2, I‚Äôm convinced this game is the purest form of emotional Stockholm Syndrome. It‚Äôs a masterpiece and a mistake, a love story and a toxic relationship, and yet every day I still find myself clicking Play like an addict convincing myself ‚Äújust one game‚Äù ‚Äî knowing full well it‚Äôll ruin my night.    Pros    + The highest highs you will ever feel gaming  Pulling off a game-winning Black Hole, landing a 5-man Ravage, or timing that perfect Echo Slam ‚Äî the dopamine is illegal. When a coordinated team play comes together, you ascend spiritually.    + Infinite skill ceiling  8,803 hours in and I still learn something new. A new ward spot, a new timing, a new way to throw the game. This thing is a never-ending education in pain and improvement. Only DotA lets you feel both genius and clown in the same match.    + The hero diversity and depth is absurd  Every patch feels like learning a new game. 125+ heroes, item reworks, map changes ‚Äî you can‚Äôt ever fully master it. And that‚Äôs the beauty. DotA is alive, unpredictable, chaotic, and brilliant.    + Teamplay that (sometimes) feels like symphony  A coordinated 5-man smoke gank is art. A well-timed Save? Poetry. When strangers understand each other without speaking ‚Äî that‚Äôs intimacy.    Cons    ‚Äì Very easy to waste your life ‚Äî I would know  8,803 hours. That‚Äôs 366 continuous days. I could‚Äôve learned a language. I could‚Äôve built a house. Instead I warded highgrounds and argued with strangers about support items.    ‚Äì Teamwork is a myth most days  For every beautiful game, there are fifty where your mid buys Midas into a losing lane and your carry farms jungle minute 48. Matchmaking is where hope goes to die.    ‚Äì Tilt is not a feeling ‚Äî it‚Äôs a lifestyle  You can win five in a row, feel like God, then one stomped match will destroy your entire sense of identity. This game doesn‚Äôt just defeat you ‚Äî it humiliates you.    ‚Äì The patch cycle makes you question your sanity  Learn everything, feel finally confident ‚Äî boom, new patch. The map grows a new cave, Roshan moves to another universe, and suddenly your favourite hero feels like a wet sock.    Final Verdict    DotA 2 is the best terrible game ever made.  It gives you euphoria and existential crisis at the same time.  I hate it. I love it.  I hate that I love it, and love that I hate it.    And tomorrow, I‚Äôll queue another match.  Because nothing else hits quite like DotA.    9/10 ‚Äî would suffer again.

This is one of the strongest games available if you enjoy theorycrafting and want a real-time strategic RPG-style PvP experience without the mechanical burden of managing large numbers of units, as in traditional RTS games.  However, the solo-queue matchmaker undermines the integrity of the game. The experience a professional Dota 2 player has is fundamentally different from what a solo-queue player encounters. I recommend Dota 1X6 in the Arcade, as it offers an FFA structure that eliminates reliance on teammates while preserving the core RPG-oriented PvP experience.  Ability Draft is also excellent, especially since hero-model drafting was introduced. I enjoy it more than the standard 5v5 mode. I cannot fairly evaluate Turbo due to limited playtime, but it appears to deliver its stated goal: shorter matches that still feel similar to Dota 2.  I do not recommend playing this game unless you can regularly assemble a party of five. The time investment is substantial, and the solo-queue return is a net negative for most players. Leaving a match mid-game harms your behavior score, so you are often locked into poor-quality matches.  The game is intensely competitive, and enjoyment heavily depends on team cooperation. You cannot be down a player and still expect a viable outcome. The community is notoriously difficult, and the archetypal Dota 2 player prioritizes shifting blame, giving up when circumstances worsen, and engaging in verbal hostility over pursuing victory.  On the ranked ladder, individual agency is limited. Provided you are neither smurfing nor griefing, your win rate converges around 40‚Äì60% regardless of personal effort. Around 40% of your wins and 40% of your losses happen largely independent of your input. The outcome is determined more by matchmaking than by individual performance. You only meaningfully influence a small fraction of 20% of your total matches from a statistical analysis perspective because you queue with four strangers whose actions outweigh your own. This is a game where being the best player doesn't mean being able to win every single match. That is, there are elements of randomness to climbing the game doesn't give 100% feedback on everything you do.  If you can consistently form a full party, the game becomes excellent. With five coordinated players, you have real strategic influence and a controlled team environment. The difficulty lies in assembling a group of four others who are not the prior mentioned archetypal Dota 2 players and whose schedules reliably align. If you can meet those conditions, the game is absolutely worth playing. Most players, however, will not be able to meet them.

As a long-time Dota 2 player since 2013, I‚Äôve witnessed the game evolve‚Äîbut not always for the better. While the core gameplay remains engaging, Valve‚Äôs approach to matchmaking and MMR has become increasingly frustrating, to the point where it feels like the system is actively working against you rather than facilitating fair competition.  -The biggest issue with Dota 2‚Äôs ranked system is its apparent forced 50% win rate mechanic. No matter how well you play, the game seems determined to keep you at a certain MMR range by stacking the odds against you, even if you‚Äôre a positive player, the game will punish you by pairing you with toxic teammates or griefers if your Behavior Score drops slightly, making climbing nearly impossible, OR  after a few wins, the system will almost always match you against significantly stronger opponents or give you weaker teammates to "balance" your progress.  - I mean back in the day, ranking up felt rewarding. Now, it feels like the system is deliberately slowing your progress to keep you playing longer, because of smurfs and boosters ruining games or due to role queue exploits!  - If you‚Äôve been playing since 2013 (like me), you‚Äôve probably noticed that Dota 2 doesn‚Äôt reward experience. Even if you take a short break, the game seems to "forget" your skill level, placing you in worse matches until you "prove yourself" again. The low to mid-tier ranks (Crusander to Legend) are where the worst matchmaking occurs‚Äîfilled with boosted accounts, griefers, and players who don‚Äôt care about winning.  - So, to conclude, if you‚Äôve been stuck in the same rank for years despite improving, it‚Äôs not (just) your fault‚Äîthe system is designed this way. Dota 2‚Äôs matchmaking doesn‚Äôt prioritize fair games it prioritizes engagement, keeping you grinding endlessly. Unless Valve makes drastic changes, the cycle of frustration will continue, making the game feel more like a chore than a rewarding experience. If you‚Äôre tired of the grind, the best solution might be to step away‚Äîbecause Dota 2 clearly doesn‚Äôt respect your time üëø

You go to unranked expecting just that a game where you can relax, learn and practice with other humans, without ruining other ppl ranked score. Instead you get matched up with very high skilled players that likely come from ranked and get reported every single time if you do a wrong move, leading to you having to wait hours on end for another game or get stuck with bots again. You can get  reported just because, the system is automated, if someone reports you because he feels like, you get temp banned regardless if you played good or bad. You go to unranked expecting to pick what you'd like and play something you feel fun, get reported for not following the latest pro meta builds and strategy, bam wait hours for another low priority quewed game. This is a horrible system that shouldn't be available in unranked, except for those cases where you break code of conduit/language insults and such, not for bad/off-meta gameplay.

Hello, my name is Miguel, I‚Ä¶ I would like to expose my pain, my anguish, my despair, and above all, my years of loneliness that were falsely hidden by this curse they call a game, and that only got worse after I learned how to play Invoker. I‚Ä¶ I deeply regret ever starting this.  The year was 2017, I was a young boy wandering and browsing the internet, I needed something to get addicted to and unfortunately, I chose this game instead of pornography or methamphetamine. You, reader, might think I‚Äôm exaggerating or using extreme situations to expose my unhappiness. But truly, honestly, maybe it would be better to be in prison right now, paying for the crime of drug use and dealing, serving my 15-year sentence and in the end‚Ä¶ in the end, seeing the sunlight and not feeling pain, guilt, sadness, and maybe, maybe, even after all of it, a desire to feel that pain again ‚Äî that pain more addictive than cocaine. Gabe Newell produced not a game, but a pact you sign, and that pact is Dota 2.  Not because it‚Äôs a bad game, not just because of that, but because it consumes you like a demon. It feeds on your pain, your sadness, your anger, and it only grows stronger. Believe me, I‚Äôm a rational guy and I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs no explanation other than supernatural for what happens when you play this game. It‚Äôs the equivalent of shoving a pineapple into your anus and, after bleeding intensely and stabilizing, ripping it out, pouring hot oil, and then pouring alcohol on top of it all. And yet, despite everything, you still feel the urge to repeat the experience.  So yes, it was a pact. I spend my time with this game while it drains my life energy, and in return, I receive trauma, I receive emptiness. I look at the world and see how much time I‚Äôve lost. I could have taken up gardening, learned sign language, become a bodybuilder, or even an astronaut!!! But instead, I was consumed and rotted little by little, until I finally broke free from the roots of evil, looked back at my past, and felt despair for not being able to rescue my younger self ‚Äî hopeful, innocent‚Ä¶  If you‚Äôre reading this, no, don‚Äôt play Dota 2. Don‚Äôt start something you cannot finish. There‚Äôs a reason why most players have over 1,000 hours and still feel regret ‚Äî and you only discover it when you‚Äôre already suffering.

Having played heros of the storm, smite, and to an extent other MOBAs, Dota has the worst new player experience by far thanks to smurfing, stunlock being a core mechanic for pretty much every single build and being killed from offscreen at max health.  I thought stunlocking was obnoxious in smite, I now see I was drastically wrong. Offscreen killings are more common than on screen once you've hit mid-later mid game. I don't want to learn this game having experienced this for four matches straight out of the new player queue (which still had smurfs in it)  I can understand why someone would enjoy this game if they put the time in. I do not want to do that. Being called shit over comms and in end game chat by the opposing team's top frag kinda cemented it for me.

I‚Äôve had a frustrating experience with this game. After taking a break and returning, I noticed an unusual pattern: initially, my allies would be significantly stronger than the enemies, making the game feel too easy. However, once I got invested, the matchmaking system seemed to change drastically. I began encountering matches filled with unskilled or toxic teammates, while the opposing team felt disproportionately powerful.  This cycle of alternating between favorable and frustrating matchups feels manipulative and disheartening. I suspect the game‚Äôs analytics and matchmaking algorithms are designed to create this pattern, which ultimately affects the enjoyment and fairness of the experience.  Unfortunately, this has impacted my mental well-being and overall experience with the game, and I‚Äôve decided to uninstall it.

My prison sentence has ended.    After roughly  6000 hours, 15 years, and enough emotional trauma to fill a small, very angry book, I'm officially filing my release papers from Dota 2.  This game is less a form of entertainment and more a slow-burning psychological experiment designed to test the absolute limits of human patience, all while teaching you creative new ways to insult strangers over the internet.    Quitting felt less like leaving a game and more like escaping an abusive relationship where I was constantly told I was 'carrying' when really I was just being used for gold and emotional baggage. The graphics are okay, I guess, if you enjoy staring at the same muddy colors and slightly unsettling character models for years on end. The gameplay is ... well, it exists. It certainly happens.    Pros:  You learn highly specialized terminology that is useless in the real world.  My life has 400% more sunlight now.    Cons:  My monitor is still sticky from the stress sweat.  I lost my favorite hoodie betting on a match I didn't understand.    In summary, this game is a masterpiece of misery. It‚Äôs highly addictive, completely soul-crushing, and I absolutely recommend that you run far, far away.    Overall Rating: 10/10 (If you measure by the sheer amount of time it can steal from a human soul)  P.S. If anyone needs me, I'll be outside, looking at a tree. I hear they're quite nice.

this game has a non fair player matching system that sends you back and forth on win/lose streaks, which keeps you on an average ELO and simultaneously keeps you hooked so that you don't uninstall. this can be easily confirmed simply by checking stats of each individual player in a game and seeing that the winning team is either on a win streak or just broke a lose streak, and the losing team is the same but inverted. if you're not outright griefing your matches, the game coordinator keeps your win rate close to 50% by teaming you with players that will either compensate your lack of skill or be much worse than players 1000 MMR below you. the only way to get to higher MMR is to create a new account and start over, not making a single mistake while you're calibrating. there is no "grind". you can't just play the game well and improve your rank. you have to play exceptionally, never make mistakes, and not count on any help from the players that the game coordinator threw into your team. it is just exhausting. the game is fun only outside ranked matchmaking

I really love this game, been playing it religiously since 2013. However, I am very disappointed with how no one is reviewing reports and banning cases in this game. I recently convinced one of my friends to try and play DOTA 2. Since he had a new account, we could only play normal matches together. I main Invoker so as broken as he is, I would normally get lots of kills and have a real presence in the map. However, due to playing Invoker how he is supposed to be played, I was reported as a smurf and ultimately got banned. I appreciate the effort that DOTA is giving to prevent smurfs and hackers from destroying the game, but I am just disappointed with how I was wrongfully banned. I tried sending an appeal, offered to give evidence that this is my only and main account, but I was only given a generic reply. I am writing this to warn people. There is a big power currently given to reports. Play well enough or piss enough number of people and you will be saying goodbye to your account. Nevertheless, the game is fun and addicting. I kind of thankful that I am unable to play so I can stop wasting time on this game LOL.   Note: the lobbies that I get matched into usually have 1-3 players in the enemy team that is either as good as me or better.  Additionally, I do not send harmful stuffs through chat at all, worse that I can say is ask "where is your bkb?" to my carry. Lastly, I spammed invoker around 5 years ago, my skills on him is definitely on a higher level compared to how I play other heroes.

I used to play this game a little bit and I remember it being pretty fun! Dude I was so wrong to download this again. If you have played a MOBA before, you will literally not be able to decipher this games cesspool of a UI system on the first try. Even if you've played Warcraft 3 through or DOTA 1. Are you ready for an RTS amount of hotkeys but you are controlling a single unit? Sure depth, pro play, get good good, blah blah blah. I'm not trying to relearn a game I've already spent like at least 500-600 hours on and already knew how to play. I could pick up League or Smite tomorrow and I'd do well and have fun!   To boot, almost every menu is a scheme to get you to play more, to get armor sets, and to buy new cosmetics. I don't care about any of that. You boot the game and you are immediately overwhelmed by a deplorable amount of Valve Classic TF2 hat garbage nothing that has to do with learning or playing the game. It's just disappointing.  In fairness, this game is immensely complex, has robust levels of play, and a totally free roster (something all other mobas lack). Pro play is fantastic to watch and there's so many unique strategies to approach a match.  If you are a real human and don't have that much time to dedicate playing video games: Don't. Play. This. You will get stuck in a feedback loop sucking Valve's downstairs and ultimately shredding your life force away. For what? An intrinsic esoteric abstraction of a single mod for Warcraft 3. Stop while you still can. Get a girlfriend, get a job, get a skillset, and for the love of Christ go and play one of the thousands of unique titles out there right now. You will enjoy yourself more, I mean it sincerely. From a guy who has played thousands of hours of these types of games.
