[h1]Dota 2 ‚Äì A Brutal Lesson in Frustration (from a LoL Veteran)[/h1]  With over 4000 hours in League of Legends, I thought I‚Äôd seen it all in the MOBA world. I expected Dota 2 to be hard, deep, maybe even rewarding in time. Instead, I found a game that actively hates new players.  [h2] Hero Design ‚Äì Welcome to the Stun-Lock Hell[/h2] Dota 2 doesn‚Äôt teach you. It punishes you. ‚Ä¢ Enemies strike from fog with absurd range. ‚Ä¢ You're stunned before you see them. ‚Ä¢ You're deleted before you can blink. ‚Ä¢ There‚Äôs no counterplay, no outplay, no escape.  This isn't a learning curve ‚Äì it‚Äôs a spike through your skull.  [h2] Thrown Into the Fire, Alone[/h2] I requested a coach. No one came. There‚Äôs no tutorial that actually helps. No guidance. No mentoring. You're tossed into matches with veterans who will tear you apart, and if you ask for help? Expect pings, flames, or silence.  Dota 2 doesn‚Äôt care if you‚Äôre learning. It just wants you to suffer or quit.  [h2] The Item System ‚Äì Designed to Confuse, Not Enhance[/h2] ‚Ä¢ Active items with no visual clarity ‚Ä¢ Courier juggling like it‚Äôs StarCraft ‚Ä¢ Recipes that make zero sense ‚Ä¢ Mandatory outside research just to function  I spent more time alt-tabbing to Wikis than actually playing the game. At some point I asked myself: Is this even fun anymore?  [h2] Chaos Disguised as Depth[/h2] Early game? Slow and punishing. Mid game? Fog ganks and surprise deaths. Late game? Blink in, die instantly, stare at death screen.  I didn‚Äôt get better. I got numb and I couldn‚Äôt learn from my mistakes because I didn‚Äôt even understand what killed me.  It‚Äôs not "deep gameplay." It‚Äôs opaque and abusive game design.  [h2] Community ‚Äì Gatekeeping on Steroids[/h2] ‚Ä¢ Ask a question? Get mocked. ‚Ä¢ Die once? "Report noob." ‚Ä¢ Try to play safe? "Why u no help?"  This isn't a community. It's a fortress of elitism, and if you‚Äôre not already inside, you're just cannon fodder.

This game genuinely changed my life for the worse. The moment i opened this game my mother was hit by a truck tire flying at 200km/h after a brutal accident. After she died, it turned out that she misspelled my name in the will and everything she left me was sent to a random person. After that, I sat down and tried to play the game, but my chair broke and i fell onto the floor. In anger, i threw my broken chair at a wall, which made my entire house collapse. Because my house collapsed, all my possessions were buried under the rubble and the only thing that remained was my PC setup. I tried to calm down by playing some Dark Souls III, but my steam library glitched and now the only game I can play is Overwatch 2. While I was playing, I got a phone call saying that I had been convicted for murder and was going to prison for life, because when I collapsed my house, the shock wave caused my neighbours cooking oil to tip onto his turned on gas stove, which blew him up immediately. When I got to prison, they said I was being sentenced to death, and asked for my last meal. I wanted a Big Mac no pickles, but McDonalds got the order wrong and gave me a cold McChicken with extra pickles. Don't trust the price tag on this game, it seems cheap but the cost is really much higher than the actual price tag. This game has ruined my life.

Dota 2 is an amazing game, that is better then the fucking league in every way i like. The reason because this review is negative is because this game pretty much fucked up my life. Is it majorly because of my irresponsibility? Sure. But no game other than this is nearly as addictive once you get into it. It was a dark period of me living in my 14m¬≤ playing this game for up to 16 hours per day, with this game giving me illusion of accomplishment with each win, and a need to get my MMR back whenever I lose. A neverending cycle of dopamine rush and withdrawal. Stopping playing it was the best decision of my life. If you ever realise that you are spending too much time in this game - uninstall it and promise to yourlelf that you will never play it again, even when the friends are asking you. If you are responsible or already have an established life thay you are reasonably happy with - this game probably won't hurt you, and it may be good for you. But if you are an irresponsible student with ADHD like me - don't ever even think about getting into this. Because if you like it, you might end up like me.

I came back to Dota after years and I can't believe what you've done to it. I search for ranked matches in West EU. Literally in every game more than half of the players are from countries other than West EU. Everywhere is full of Russians or Ukrainians. They shout into the voice chat in their own language. They flood the chat text with meaningless characters that no one understands. There's nothing you can do about it. As soon as you politely ask these monkeys for English, that they play in Western Europe, you get even more Russian and Ukrainian as an answer. This is not fun, friends. It really is not. The only option is to mute everyone, but then I can go play any singleplayer and I'll have the same experience. I can't play on more Western servers because of the ping.  I absolutely don't understand why I can't ban heroes in ranked games. The game itself bans heroes completely randomly. What's the point of that?  There is no system in the game to give up a game you've already lost. For example, in a game where everyone is yelling at each other in Ukrainian and Russian. In a game where the pick fails and in the 10th minute the score is 0:20 and it is clear to everyone that it is a loss. In such games you make the players suffer another 20-50 minutes. For leaving earlier and saving nerves and mental health you penalize. Because you don't want the players to have fun. You want them to suffer until the last second. This is not fun, friends. It really is not.  There are many similar games like your Dota on the market. Just get inspired by others. Take the best from them. What you are missing. And for God's sake implement it. You have been working on the game for 12 years and it really doesn't look like that.  In its current state, Dota is almost unplayable. It has nothing to do with fun.

I must say, this is a creative game collecting vinyl records, lighters, and troll dolls satisfies many people's collecting obsessions.  However, this game has fatal flaws:  1. Object collision detection is unresolved. For a game developed using the Unreal Engine, failing to implement even the most basic functionality makes it a poorly made product.  The consequences are severe: a. Players can use any bullet to kill other players through any obstacle.  b. Characters can embed themselves inside buildings, making them visible to people outside.  2. The bullet trajectory is completely wrong bullets travel almost straight, with no fall or wind drift. Only simple recoil and breathing causing aiming deviation are present.  Bullets are completely unaffected by initial velocity, allowing for arbitrarily long ranges.  For example, I can easily kill someone with two shots from a shotgun at 30 yards,  while a Thompson submachine with a lower initial velocity, at 10-20 yards, can hit four or more bullets without killing them.  3. One-third of the players are cheaters becuz cheat codes are open source, meaning 2-3 out of every 9 players in a match are cheaters.  Even with cheat codes, some people are very good at pretending to be innocent. However, some players don't care at all and go unpunished.  Here are a few simple examples of cheating:  a. Invincible type: They don't take any damage no matter what you do.  b. X-ray vision type: They know your location, your equipment, and the mines and traps you've planted. If your equipment is weak, they'll chase you if you've planted mines, they won't go near them.  You crouch behind a rock and wait for them when they come, they just shoot through the rock and get a headshot.  c. Auto-aiming type: You can't kill them within 10 yards behind them (because it's difficult to aim at the head while running and the bullet trajectory is incorrect), but they can turn around and get a headshot in 0.1 seconds.  4. For many average players, waiting 3 or even 10 minutes to team up, only to be killed less than a minute into the game, makes for a terrible gaming experience.  As a veteran shooter who never uses cheats, my kill/death ratio in typical shooters is 8:1, even with a few encounters with cheaters.  In this game, however, my kill/death ratio is below 1:10.  I'm a special player I enjoy playing against cheaters because it greatly improves my skills. That's why I can achieve an 8:1 ratio in other shooters.  But not in this game.  5. To adapt to the harsh game environment, no matter how bad it is, play the game, don't let the game play you.  I adopted a strategic approach, treating it like a survival mini-game, completely avoiding direct head-on shootouts with other players, because humans simply cannot overcome auto-aiming and wallhacks you have no chance.  So I imagined it as the game having eight other "robot terminators," and I need to use my wits to gather resources and escape safely.  I never use any high-quality guns once you carry one, there's a 90% chance of losing it, so I only carry a Thompson or nothing at all.  I became the weekly champion after only 3 days of playing.  6. Due to the terrible gaming experience, there are very few players, probably only a few hundred, so the wait time is quite long. Most of them are new players who joined because the game is free.  7. Finally, a word of advice to game developers: don't outsource game development anymore. Even the best ideas can turn into disasters.

The game looks pretty nice, better than lol and as good as hots or even better. I like that the map is flipped instead of mirrored and that there is a day and night cycle. Im a noob in this genre and this game seems more overwhelming than its competitors, which makes the tutorials more important. There are a ton of tutorials but a lot of them seem broken or out of order (a test game comes before the movement tutorial). Tutorials like the teleportation one or the middle game one (which introduces the shop a bit more) do not progress and are just stuck on step 1. The community tutorial also doesn't work as there are no messages on screen on what to do. I guess at some time it used to work but now its just broken. New players are forced to use other sources to learn the basics of the game, such as youtube. Im okay with that if its a single player game or if figuring the game out is an intended part of the experience. Unfortunately moba is a highly competitive genre, where I like to go into games prepared and with a full understanding of all mechanics. Please fix your tutorials valve and I will change my review to positive.

I will tell you about my negative experience and why i dont think its a "healty gameplay experience" and you can decide for yourselves.    I am playing ranked games to enter which u need to play 100 hours first to sort of learn the game and then calibrate your rank , i don't really care about rank itself but its the only mode to play if you care to minimise matchups where your teammates or opponents teammates will "TRY" to win and play game with "less griefing or afk" . Once your in Ranked you have choice to play Role based mode or Classic mode , which is there to determine your hero picks and position on map and your role in team.    My biggest issue with the game is how rank system and behaviour system works and how tools that determine those numbers "work" (spoiler - they are not). Let me give you example which happened to me almost every third game : I play ranked role , select hero and role (i choose all roles as i can play any and mostly get assigned to support or offlane) what usually happens - you get put in a matchup with people who are in premade pairs or trios in your team , so you end up with (you) (two friends) (two friends) or (you) (three friends) (solo guy) , this happens alot - but what happens next is leading to negative experience based on tools in game - those players who are together with a chance of 80% based on my games will play their own game and only interact with each other - most of the time they will flame (toxic) you or other single player and blame those who are not in their premade group for everything that went wrong iin game in their believe (human nature)  ... in result you will keep getting reports from those people almost 90% of games you loose and even if you win game in the end they would still throw reports if they believe you didnt play well . And trust me , for every third game you get that WIN or Lose ... This will drop your behavior score down - which will result in u unable to communicate , ping , make calls ,etc in your games untill your behaviour score goes up ( which never does - the more you play the lower it goes , and trust me - i didnt even communicate or being toxic cus i couldnt - game prevents me) the more u play - the lower it will eventually go .    My point is - tools designed to improve game - actually ruin it for you big time , because people have no penalty of spamming reports and they can do it for reason or without it , in every single match you play .    And not being able to communicate in a team game with your team - takes away a major aspect of this game and a very important aspect - sometimes a few good team calls can win you game and bring morale back in case its down . Imagine you are a part of squad at war but nobody can talk to each other -  you can see each other yes-  but you cant tell each other what is the plan ... in a game of dota2 it is a crucial aspect to win a match imho. Especially in lower ranks where people still learn and you can help each other and point out where to go , what items to suggest and etc.   So - your rank drops faster since you cant communicate , since your behaviour score also drops , and you keep getting people with same rank and behaviour in your games - they also cant talk to each other .   And believe me you dont even have to do anything bad - people will keep reporting you almost every game , just cus they can . Either mad that you lost and spam report to entire team or cus of their own mental issues ! ... Been there.   Now ask yourself why would you play a game with such a system in place , that will take away lots of time , a game that requires a lot of time to learn and even more to master - just to end up not being able to even communicate on the battlefield in the time of need... you simply cant play effective when team cant coordinate in this game... BTW - every time you get reports - you can also end up penalised for 4 hrs  - not being able to play , this penalty can go up to 24 hrs and so on - and after you will have to play Single Draft mode and obligated to win 1-4 games depending on penalty - to get back into Ranked mode.   And culmination of this - if your account will drop below 2k behaviour score - you will not be able to play Ranked games at all . It takes time to get so low - but remember - once you go down to 6k behaviour score - its only a way down - how fast  - depends on luck .   Nicely designed tools , right ? what you think is it worth it ?

This game absorbed my college life and visibly influence my growing process. I stopped around 3k-ish hours because I finally realized I got more important things to do...  The game is truthfully awful in every way imaginable, but that's the beauty of it. All sort of phychological traits start to emerge and it can be a reflection process throughout, as if you get free therapy sessions:  1. Mental Health Growth - Realize I might be procrastinating and play the game to feel good in order to get worse (knowingly). - You will Blame yourself, but others do too... So you can both reflect on how to blame passively, just like those co-workers I hate in the office.  2. Ego-pride Conduct - Playing Gracefully? WRONG | Advising Teammate? WRONG | Muting the Game? WRONG... so what is RIGHT? --> Exactly.  3. Organization - Each of your own friend/teammate have a role in-game. The funny thing is, you know how they fare IRL compared to when they are in-game. Then you know how lame players are actually cool IRL. - Planning, scheming, synergizing... These are old school. You should just wait for the patch, just like how the world always reset itself in each financial crisis.   All in all, I thank all of those who played with me. I can see how these addicted fellows do in life Right Now compared to when they played with me in my college years (around 500-1000hrs) and I can say: majority of them uninstall the game and don't look back. Dota 2 is an amazing game with deep strategy, great heroes, and a lot of skill expression. The gameplay itself is seriously fun and addictive.  But the community can be extremely toxic, and the report/behavior system feels really unfair. You can join a match, play calmly, communicate, and do your best ‚Äî and still get reported just because your team lost and someone wants to blame you. Even worse, a toxic teammate can report you for no reason, and you end up getting punished anyway. Your behavior score drops, and sometimes you even get bans that feel completely undeserved.  The game is great, but the experience is often ruined by the toxic environment and a report system that‚Äôs too easy to abuse. Valve really needs to improve moderation and make reports more accurate and harder to misuse.

This review will mostly concern those players that might be asking themselves: Should I come back?  Short answer: Hell no.  I came back after a long, long break (I stopped playing after MK release and came back shortly in 2022ish for Marci) and I was curious how the game really is all these years later. They made the game accessible to anybody, heroes have passives and facets (which you select before the game to alter your hero), talent tree is still not removed for some reason, heroes have no identity, they all can carry the game for some reason. Some beloved heroes have been changed a little, some like Omniknight are completely different for no reason whatsoever. Why change something that was fine? Aghanim's shard is a joke, the woods and map are completely changed for the worse, Roshan now patrols the river for some reason and will throw you aside for a billion damage if you get in his way, scan is a thing for some reason giving you pings in are if enemy moves there, there are shrines where you get free XP so even a clown can stay in levels since they killed the roaming support archetype, there are free healing items on the side of the map instead of the shop, teleporting gates from one side of the map to the other, every hero can kill wards even on high ground even if they're melee...  I can go on and on forever. They added so much unnecessary garbage that the game can hardly even considered DotA anymore. This game should be called Dota 2: Electric Boogaloo League of Legends Bang Bang Rift.  This is not DotA, this is not the DotA experience. Might as well play the DotA on Frozen Throne for the true experience. What a joke, what a disaster. OG game ruined this much and for what? Ease of access to new players? Making the game modern and make it play for the worse. Goodbye DotA may I never see you again.

Having 100 characters means there are 99 enemies you have to learn to combat, if you chose to stick with the same character. If you switch, since games are 30 minutes, that's 1500 hours of game play you'd have to complete to know which character is best for you...That's just dumb.    if you're going to study something read Grey's Anatomy. It'd take me months just to read through what the characters can do. The interface for doing so is awful. Then there's items. Thousands of items, some only viewable at certain times. This game was made for AI to play. not a human.    The matchmaking is AWFUL. Absolute trash. Unranked matches means no matchmaking protocol. You get who you get and you need to sit through 50 games to go ranked to find a balance mechanism in the matchmaking.    I don't understand why playing against people who one shot you at range is fun for me as a beginner. Why would i ever keep playing this game?    Its sad that those who enjoy this game, the majority of players are unranked or low level ranked, thats how the numbers work, based solely on their ability to play new players.    It's like some people get off playing only against significantly weaker competition.    Oh btw, after your first month everything you do is worse because they boost your performance early to make you think you can hang. I dont have to play a whole month to see how this works.Randomly ill log in one day and Ill be nerfed simply because I chose to keep playing.    The character models are bad. Straight up. They look terrible.    Someone explain how a ranged attacker who can stealth and one shot, or can slow and enemy and do hundreds of AoE damage after only a few levels can ever be beat by a slow walking melee idiots who hits just as hard and as slow as any other character? Where's the balance?    Oh use items. Thats how you balance. So back to reading...love reading while playing games.    The items are so fun to read its like LOTR good! When youre done you feel so accomplished for now knowing you dont want most of the items! What fun!    At least they knew people wouldnt buy it. I can't believe these devs make so much money off of kids and the mentally incompetent.

Dota is a completely broken game. For the last few weeks, the Dota servers disconnect from me, I get an error message that says "No longer communicating with game servers," then I am the one who gets penalized (I have to wait 3 minutes before I'm allowed to queue again, as if I disconnected from the lobby).    In addition, Dota's ranking/matchmaking is completely broken. I am constantly placed in all Spanish-speaking or Russian or Chinese-speaking lobbies, despite only queueing up for North American servers. Then these guys all report me because I can't understand their languages. So MY behavior/communication score gets worse.    And, last, I am a new player with not too many hours in the game, but I constantly play against VERY GOOD players whose accounts are only one or two days old. They are called "smurfs" and they are ruining my games. But in the end, I'm the one who gets reported by them and their parties.    What a total joke from a "Steam-developed" game. There is no development going on, not really. The behavior system is totally broken.

Dota 2 is an incredibly deep and exciting game with endless strategic possibilities. The gameplay, hero variety, and constant updates make every match feel unique and rewarding. I‚Äôve enjoyed many great moments, and the competitive environment keeps the experience intense and engaging. However, one major issue that holds the game back is the smurfing problem. It affects match quality and can make games feel unfair, especially for newer or lower-ranked players. I really hope the developers take stronger action to balance and reduce smurfs in the game. Overall, Dota 2 is a fantastic experience, but with better handling of smurf accounts, it could be even more enjoyable for everyone.

Dota 2 could be an amazing game. The mechanics are deep, the hero roster is huge, and trying different hero/item combinations can actually be really fun. There‚Äôs so much potential for creativity and experimentation‚Ä¶ in theory.  But the problem is simple: the community does not let you enjoy any of that.  The moment you try something new‚Äîsomething even slightly outside the sacred ‚Äúmeta‚Äù‚Äîyou‚Äôre instantly blamed for everything. People act like there‚Äôs only one correct way to play every hero, one mandatory item path, and any attempt to innovate automatically means you‚Äôre throwing the game. It‚Äôs suffocating. And the worst part? It‚Äôs not even true. Non-meta builds can win. But try telling that to teammates who explode the second you buy anything they didn‚Äôt see in a pro match last week.  What could be an interesting and creative strategy game ends up feeling like a strict, joyless homework assignment. You queue up hoping to have fun, and instead you get five strangers treating you like a criminal because you dared to build something different.  And yes‚Äîmatches last forever. It‚Äôs a massive time sink, and for what? To get yelled at for trying to enjoy yourself?  Verdict: A deep, potentially brilliant game completely dragged down by a community that refuses to let players explore, experiment, or have fun. If you value your time‚Äîand your sanity‚Äîyou might want to stay away

Dota 2 bursts onto the scene with a chaotic symphony of heroes, items, and strategies that can feel like conducting a battlefield orchestra‚Äîwhen it clicks, those comeback victories and perfect ganks deliver pure adrenaline highs. The depth is staggering: Endless builds, map control mind games, and team synergies reward smart plays with euphoric triumphs  But for me, the steep learning cliff and punishing match lengths (often 45+ minutes of tilt-inducing wipes) turn it into a grind that outstays its welcome. Toxicity creeps in, and without that competitive fire, it fizzles into frustration more than fun. Solid for the die-hards, but it just didn't hook this player  5/10 ‚Äì Impressive spectacle, middling match for my tastes.

After 4,000 hours of playing Dota 2‚Ä¶ I‚Äôve finally figured it out. This game is the ultimate soul-draining time-devouring machine disguised as a free game.  The only thing you‚Äôll truly gain here isn‚Äôt skill, and it‚Äôs definitely not new friends. It‚Äôs a toxic relationship strong enough to break through the gates of hell.  Dota 2 is a game where you win, yet somehow feel like you lost. Because by the end of each match, you may have flamed someone a few times, or gotten flamed who-knows-how-many more.  The entire internet combined still isn‚Äôt as toxic as the Dota community. Every curse word, every language, every accent compressed perfectly into every single match for your premium consumption.  And yet, I‚Äôm still playing. Because I can‚Äôt quit. I‚Äôve already become addicted to my own sadness.  Score: 11/10 If you want to waste your life stylishly, this is the game for you.  And finally, I sincerely recommend this: You‚Äôll become a better person the moment you quit this stupid game.

It was once worth it.    Horrid Reporting System:  It's not easy getting back your rating. I went down from 11000 to 3000. I just got back to 7000.  I've played this Game since it's inception and it's really toxic. ^That's why their is a mute button.    Here's the rundown - Those muted toxic people, they have ways of bring you down to their level.    How to be Toxic 101.  Step 1: Team-up with Toxic people (4/3 squad).  Step 2: Queue.  Step 3: See Pos 5/4/3/2/1 player pick.  Step 4: Ask for Pos 5/4/3/2/1.  Step 5: Get Denied.  Step 6: Bully the player that doesn't do what you want.  Step 7: Feed.  Step 8: Complain that said player isn't doing something after dying.  Step 9: Verbally abuse the player  Step 10: Report player for saying/typing/doing anything. (typing "gg" counts as text chat, saying hello counts as voice chat, farming creeps when your teleportation scroll is on cooldown counts as behavior.)  Step 11: Bait the player and leave them to die. then report for griefing.  Step 12: Feed by soloing 5 enemies, then go in 1 by 1, then report the last one alive for griefing.  Step 13: Ignore teammate because they weren't at 1 fight or did something to fracture your tiny ego.    Alternatively as a Solo player you can always.  -Jungle til the end of the game and cost all 4 the game.  -Spam the same voice lines constantly when off cooldown.   -Solo the enemies whenever you return from certain death.  -Some heroes/items can troll their teammates. (Bane, Rubick, Tiny, Venge, Forcestaff and more.)    I was matched up with/against familiar toxic players who reported me every game I played with/against them. I know this because you can see when and how many reports you received, so you can work out when you match-up with the same names and get the same amount of reports. *multiple times.     Once they matched up enough against you. You get start losing your rating 700 points a day. I tried using the avoid function that comes with Plus. They just end up on the other team and report you again.   The irony is that valve accepts a report from the same player that technically would have had to report you for chat/voice which toggles you as muted, then they would remove mute and report you again. (Why  is that a thing, by un-muting they are agreeing to see/hear whatever that player was muted for previously.)    Those toxic players that are genuinely toxic, they just buy or create a new account and you end up in a whirlpool of toxic sludge, sinking deeper and deeper until you learn that the only way back is to say absolutely nothing, no calls, no strategy, no assisting, not even a "gg".    When you start and get past waiting for ages for a match-up, after multiple matches against or with the same 4 stack of griefers mass reporting you. Until you are in a lower tier, then everyone reports you for anything and everything, so you just get lower. The only way to get back up is to not speak, or ping, or use the voice lines you get with plus.     Essentially paying to have horrid match-ups.     I just made it back to 7000, I can't even advise someone as a more experienced player without it being treated as toxic. Rarely a match-up is acceptable, if not it's some teammate that can't play because they don't do the freaking tutorial. Then it's someone that doesn't know there are 5 positions for a reason. The deeper you go, the worse it gets, 3 games in a row with at least 2 griefers. That stop playing 1 minute into the game because their teammate picked the same position or died once or didn't stack a camp or didn't follow them into certain death.     @valve Just keep muted players muted, if you choose to un-mute, then you are agreeing that you cannot report that player again for chat/voice. I'd rather have 4 muted toxic players that can't report me out of spite than this reporting system that gives them power. Surely you can get a formula that matches in-game behaviour based on the player and not the toxic teammates.    This review took way too long and there is so much more but just writing this is upsetting.

While I appreciate Valve effort to make the game Linux compatible, it is quite unstable given it is a competitive and old game. it crashed very often. then players try to reconnect. If you dont manage to reconnect within 5 min, Hell  boy, the game will make you pay for it. Prevents you for playing for 1 day, moves you to low priority matchmaking queues,  does not allow you to chat (even to plan an attack or anything) and only makes you play I kind of game where you hero is picked randomly.  Most of the time, Steam will prevent the game from running after a crash and will make you wait 10-20 minutes to "download content". I still have no idea what that content is, but you can be sure that after being put into the low priority status, you wont be content for long.  Overall, the game improves the mechanics of DOTA 1 and delivers fast dopamine, but the punitive system regarding the disconnections is unbearable given the constant crashes. Tried to climb out of the low priority queue, but it is impossible.  it is filled with trash players and the crashes made my situation worst.  This game will make you frustrated and unhappy. STAY AWAY

I've been playing dota for years, but honestly, this game has turned into a massive disappointment. It keeps crashing for no reason and its definitely not my PC‚Äôs fault. My specs can handle far heavier games smoothly, yet dota keeps freezing and crashing like it‚Äôs still in early beta access. Imagine losing mmr or wasting time because of poor optimization that‚Äôs never fixed.    I finally gave up and switched to Xbox and Battle.net to play FPS games and you know what? The experience is miles better. Even though steam has a lot of fps titles, I chose to leave it completely because steam and valve have become so unreliable. Their systems feel outdated, their games feel neglected, and the overall experience just isn‚Äôt worth it anymore.    What‚Äôs even worse is how dota‚Äôs integrity keeps falling apart. Even my long time dota friends have quit because the game feels unfair and broken. The matchmaking algorithm is a joke once you go on a win streak, the system suddenly matches you with impossible lineups just to ruin your momentum. It doesn‚Äôt matter if you play well or maintain good behavior the algorithm feels punishing instead of rewarding.    And to make things even more frustrating, valve can‚Äôt even properly handle account recovery issues. When someone else gets access to your account, you‚Äôll go through endless verification steps. Even if you already have solid evidence proving you‚Äôre the real owner, they‚Äôll keep demanding more and more details like they don‚Äôt even want to help you recover it. It‚Äôs a complete waste of time.    At this point, I‚Äôm done. This game sucks, and valve has completely lost its touch. The passion, fairness, and fun that once made dota great are gone. The company doesn‚Äôt listen, the support is terrible, and the quality keeps going downhill.    I‚Äôll never use steam or any valve game again. Dota‚Äôs legacy is fading fast, and Gen Z players don‚Äôt even care about it anymore. valve needs to wake up ‚Äî because the way things are going, dota is no longer a legend‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs just another forgotten game.

Dota 2: A Beautifully Abusive Relationship  I‚Äôve been playing Dota 2 for over 8 years now, which is roughly the same length of time it takes to develop Stockholm Syndrome. Except instead of being kidnapped by a masked villain, I willingly installed the game. Repeatedly. Even after uninstalling it. Multiple times. Because this time, I swore I was done.  Every match begins with hope: ‚ÄúThis is the one. I‚Äôll have fun.‚Äù But within minutes, some guy named ‰Ω†Â¶àÂ¶àÊ≤°ÊúâÊØõ picks Techies, feeds first blood, tells me I should uninstall the game and my parents clearly regretted downloading me. And yet, I stay.  Dota 2 is the only place where I can experience the five stages of grief within 30 minutes, multiple times a day, and still queue up again like it‚Äôs a warm hug from a cold ex who swears they‚Äôve changed. (They haven‚Äôt. IceFrog just adjusted the patch notes.)  Would I recommend Dota 2? Absolutely not. Do I love it? No. Does it love me back? No. Do I care? Apparently not.  Help.

The neon glow of the computer shop flickered against the rain outside. Inside, rows of gamers sat hunched over their keyboards, faces lit by the chaotic swirl of spells and explosions on-screen. Diego had been playing Dota 2 for years. Thousands of hours, countless sleepless nights, and yet‚Äîevery match felt like rolling dice with fate. Tonight, he swore it would be different. Tonight, he would climb out of the trench of despair known as Herald rank. The draft began. His teammates argued instantly. ‚ÄúPick carry!‚Äù one shouted. ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm mid!‚Äù another barked. Diego sighed and locked in Crystal Maiden. Support again. The thankless role. The horn sounded, and the battle began. For the first ten minutes, everything went well. Diego warded, stacked camps, and saved allies with clutch Frostbite. But then it happened‚Äîthe curse of Dota. His carry disconnected. His midlaner bought a Divine Rapier at 15 minutes. His offlaner spammed chat: ‚ÄúGG go next.‚Äù The enemy team snowballed. Towers fell like dominoes. Diego fought desperately, but every spell felt like throwing water at a wildfire. Finally, the Ancient crumbled. Defeat. The screen flashed: -25 MMR. Diego leaned back, staring at the ceiling. The rain outside had stopped, but inside, the storm raged on. He whispered to himself: ‚ÄúWhy do I keep coming back?‚Äù And then, as if answering, the game client chimed: ‚ÄúSearching for next match‚Ä¶‚Äù Diego laughed bitterly. Dota wasn‚Äôt just a game‚Äîit was a trap. A labyrinth where victory was fleeting, teammates were enemies, and time itself was the final boss. Yet tomorrow, he knew he‚Äôd sit down again, chasing that one perfect match that never truly existed.
